2021-02-06 11:30:58#local#Democrats Will Regret Their Move against Marjorie Taylor Greene#https://news.yahoo.com/democrats-regret-move-against-marjorie-113058115.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/xW12fSXluPB2OyNRy4zbwQ--~B/aD00NjQ7dz03OTY7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en/the_national_review_738/0b2071b32c0e5576df0508f572842647#en#-0.4215#news.yahoo.com#At least Marjorie Taylor Greene won’t have to spend time sitting at the end of the dais during long committee hearings.  House Democrats voted to boot her from her committee assignments in an act that they will surely come to regret
column2: perhaps as soon as January 2023.  If the majority can keep members of the opposition party off of committees based on incendiary comments
column3: it’s not clear why the GOP ever let
column4: say
column5: Maxine Waters serve on any committees when it had control of the chamber
column6: or why it ever will again.  Kicking off Greene will come to be remembered as another inflection point in the steady unraveling of institutional norms on Capitol Hill.  That said
column7: we believe that Republicans should have taken matters into their own hands and denied Greene her committee assignments to draw a line against malicious lunacy in their own ranks.  That Democrats had a gun to his head with their threat to have a floor vote on Greene’s committee assignments probably made it more politically difficult for Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy to act on his own.  He did seek a deal with the Democrats to take her off the House Committee on Education and Labor and the Budget Committee and instead relegate her to the Small Business Committee.  When Democrats didn’t bite
column8: McCarthy again condemned her past comments and wrung an expression of regret from her in an internal GOP meeting earlier in the week that she repeated on the House floor on Thursday.  Her statement didn’t ring with sincerity
column9: but it was better than nothing
column10: even if she was immediately holding a combative press conference where she said
column11: “I’m fine with being kicked off committees because it’d be a waste of my time. ” We have
column13: not heard the last of her. #https://news.yahoo.com/democrats-regret-move-against-marjorie-113058115.html#RwBEmsorR

column1: 2021-02-06 15:55:00#local#Former CIA officer explains why Biden is right not to 'run the risk' of sending Trump intelligence briefings#https://news.yahoo.com/former-cia-officer-explains-why-155500145.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/_v045rXI4e0JPTdPZkQLQg--~B/aD01NjA7dz04NDA7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en/the_week_574/62d5ddbd45af7ace5e955b5682cde3da#en#0.25#news.yahoo.com#"President Biden told CBS News' Norah O'Donnell he doesn't think former President Donald Trump should receive classified intelligence briefings
column2: questioning whether there's any upside to it and suggesting Trump's ""erratic behavior"" could lead to him eventually revealing sensitive information pertaining to national security.  It's not clear if Biden will officially cut off Trump's access
column3: but such a move would be unprecedented — traditionally
column4: former presidents can request and receive briefings.  David Priess
column5: who briefed former President George H. W.  Bush for many years after he left office
column6: told The Washington Post that ex-presidents continue to receive intelligence briefings because even though they're no longer in an official position of power
column7: they are considered representatives of the United States
column8: especially by foreign leaders
column9: for the rest of their lives.  He added that presidents also may turn to their predecessors for advice on international affairs.  That said
column10: Priess agrees with Biden that an exception could be made for Trump since ""there's no chance of Biden reaching out to Trump . . .  So why would Biden run the risk of Trump's disclosure of sensitive information by agreeing to such briefings?"" Journalist Yashar Ali did note that former presidents can also interact with other governments privately
column11: as former President Bill Clinton did when he traveled to North Korea in 2009 to secure the release of two journalists being held there.  Clinton
column13: notes was briefed even though it wasn't an official U. S.  government trip.  2.  For example
column14: when President Clinton when to North Korea to secure the release of two journalists who were being held by Kim Jong-Il
column15: he was given an intelligence briefing even though the trip was a private one and not an official US government trip.  — Yashar Ali (@yashar) February 6
column17: Trump wasn't exactly known for devouring his daily briefings while in office
column18: so it's not clear sending them now would offer the Biden administration much comfort
column19: either way.  More stories from theweek. comHarris has reportedly pushed Biden's coronavirus team to focus on overlooked communitiesSenator Ivanka?'Explosive' Woody Allen documentary featuring video account from 7-year-old Dylan Farrow to debut on HBO"#https://news.yahoo.com/former-cia-officer-explains-why-155500145.html#LEA8XGLN1

column1: 2021-02-05 13:07:58#health#Fecal microbe transplants help cancer patients respond to immunotherapy and shrink tumors#https://news.yahoo.com/fecal-microbe-transplants-help-cancer-130758373.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/Hp1nUNElh5BzNc5YabAvIQ--~B/aD0xNDM4O3c9MTQ0MDthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en/the_conversation_us_articles_815/8459a406da3938ebb32ee4703aaa0dca#en#-0.4019#news.yahoo.com#The gut is filled with microbes that can affect human health.  ChrisChrisW/iStock via Getty Images PlusThe effect of a drug
column2: or impact of a treatment like chemotherapy
column3: doesn’t just depend on your body.  The success of a particular medicine also depends on the trillions of bacteria in your gut.  The 100 trillion bacteria that live within the human digestive tract – known as the human gut microbiome – help us extract nutrients from food
column4: boost the immune response and modulate the effects of drugs.  Recent research
column6: has implicated the gut microbiome in seemingly unconnected states
column7: ranging from the response to cancer treatments to obesity and a host of neurological diseases
column8: including Alzheimer’s
column9: Parkinson’s disease
column10: depression
column11: schizophrenia and autism.  What underlies these apparently discrete observations is the unifying idea that the gut microbiota send signals beyond the gut and that these signals have broad effects on a large swathe of target tissues.  I am a medical oncologist whose research involves developing novel therapies for melanoma.  To evaluate whether altering the microbiome could benefit cancer patients
column12: my colleagues and I evaluated the transfer of fecal matter from melanoma patients who responded well to immunotherapy to those patients for whom immunotherapy failed.  Just published in the journal Science
column13: our results reveal that this treatment helped shrink the tumors of advanced melanoma patients when other therapies hadn’t worked.  What connects cancer and gut bacteria? Gut microbiota have been linked to to the success and failure of multiple cancer treatments
column14: including chemotherapy and cancer immunotherapy with immune checkpoint inhibitors such as nivolumab and pembrolizumab.  In the more recent studies
column15: the species and relative populations of gut bacteria determined the probability that a cancer patient would respond to drugs known as “immune checkpoint inhibitors. ” This research showed that differences in the gut microbiome between individual patients were associated with various outcomes to these drugs.  But the precise mechanisms underlying microbiome-immune interactions remain unclear.  Can fecal microbes help drugs reach hard to treat melanoma? Oncologists often treat patients with advanced melanoma using immunotherapies targeting specific proteins on the surface of immune cells known as PD-1 and CTLA-4.  These work in a subset of patients
column16: however – 50%-70% of patients have cancers that get worse despite treatment.  No medical treatments have been approved to treat melanoma patients who have failed PD-1 immunotherapies.  To investigate whether certain types of microbes could boost the efficacy of PD-1 immunotherapies
column17: my colleagues and I developed a study in which we collected fecal microbes from patients who had responded well to this therapy and administered these to cancer patients who didn’t benefit from the checkpoint drugs.  Cancer patients who responded well to immunotherapy donated stool samples.  Their stool was processed to yield material for a fecal microbe transplant.  Diwakar Davar
column18: CC BY-ND We chose stool from patients who responded well to immunotherapy based on the hunch that they would have greater quantities of bacteria implicated in helping shrink the cancer.  As it is difficult to identify one or two species of bacteria that are responsible for the beneficial response to these therapies
column19: we used the entire bacterial community – hence fecal microbe transplant.  Transplant recipients were patients whose melanoma had never responded to immunotherapy.  Both recipients and donors underwent screening for diseases to ensure that no infectious agents would be transmitted during the transplant.  Following a biopsy of their tumor
column20: patients received a fecal microbe transplant from patients who benefited from immunotherapy along with a drug called called pembrolizumab
column21: which was continued every three weeks.  My colleagues and I assessed the fecal microbe transplant 12 weeks after the treatment.  Patients whose cancers had shrunk or remained the same size after the fecal microbe transplant continued to receive pembrolizumab for up to two years.  Results of novel clinical trial Cancer patients who responded poorly to immunotherapy were given a fecal microbe transplant from a cancer patient who did well and a drug called pembrolizumab.  For some of the patients
column22: the microbe transplant made the immunotherapy work.  Diwakar Davar
column23: CC BY-ND Following this fecal microbe transplant treatment
column24: tumors of six out of 15 patients in the study had tumors that shrank or remained the same.  The treatment was well tolerated
column25: though some of the patients experienced minor side effects including fatigue.  When we analyzed the gut microbiota of treated patients
column26: we observed that the six patients whose cancers had stabilized or improved showed increased numbers of bacteria that had previously been associated with responses to immunotherapy.  My colleagues and I also analyzed the blood and tumors from responders.  In doing so
column27: we observed that the responders had lower levels of adverse immune cells termed myeloid cells
column28: and higher levels of memory immune cells.  Additionally
column29: by analyzing proteins in the blood serum of treated patients
column30: we observed reductions in levels of key immune system molecules associated with resistance in responders.  These results suggest that introducing certain intestinal microorganisms into a patient’s colon may help the patient respond to drugs that enhance the immune system’s ability to recognize and kill tumor cells.  Ultimately we hope to move beyond fecal microbe transplants to specific collections of microbes in cancers besides melanoma
column31: paving the way for standardized microbe-based drug therapy to treat immunotherapy-resistant tumors.  [The Conversation’s science
column32: health and technology editors pick their favorite stories.  Weekly on Wednesdays. ]This article is republished from The Conversation
column33: a nonprofit news site dedicated to sharing ideas from academic experts.  It was written by: Diwakar Davar
column34: University of Pittsburgh.  Read more:A healthy microbiome builds a strong immune system that could help defeat COVID-19Bacteria live on our eyeballs – and understanding their role could help treat common eye diseases Diwakar Davar receives research funding from Arcus Biosciences
column39: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK).  Diwakar Davar receives compensation for consulting from Checkmate Pharmaceuticals

2021-02-04 20:51:00#local#Biden takes away Saudi Arabia's blank check to commit war crimes#https://news.yahoo.com/biden-takes-away-saudi-arabias-205100479.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/AfL5XhVLkGWgIbXeVByc0w--~B/aD01NjA7dz04NDA7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en/the_week_574/3733daa37f14607e2815e5bd7cb7f5bb#en#-0.4019#news.yahoo.com#The Biden administration announced Thursday that it would halt support of Saudi Arabia's offensive military operations in Yemen
column2: where the war has caused a gigantic humanitarian emergency on top of the coronavirus pandemic.  Biden will also reportedly appoint experienced diplomat Timothy Lenderking as special envoy to Yemen.  It remains to be seen exactly how this will play out
column3: but as Sen.  Bernie Sanders (I-Vt. ) noted in a statement
column4: it looks like the start of a diplomatic push to get Saudi Arabia to end the brutal war in which it has been bogged down since 2015
column6: and coordinate an international aid effort.  The Saudi military basically cannot do anything without U. S.  support
column7: and any strong signals from America that it should knock it off probably will be heeded.  That's especially true now that Trump is gone
column8: and Saudi dictator Mohammad bin Salman thus faces possible recrimination for ordering the cold-blooded murder of a U. S.  resident and Washington Post columnist
column9: Jamal Khashoggi
column10: back in 2018.  It is worth noting that while Biden is reversing a Trump decision
column11: the Yemen policy actually originated under the Obama administration.  It is a marked difference from the early months of 2009
column12: when Obama kept on George W.  Bush's secretary of defense and planned for a massive troop surge in Afghanistan.  Perhaps two decades of expensive

column1: 2021-02-04 18:24:15#tech#Metro: Last Light Redux and For the King are free on the Epic Store#https://www.pcgamer.com/metro-last-light-redux-and-for-the-king-are-free-on-the-epic-store/#https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/4GXjhhUoDDVYv7qbfJbQwP-1200-80.jpg#en#0.5106#www.pcgamer.com#"It's time once again to indulge in the weekly tradition of grabbing a free game from the Epic Games Store.  This week actually brings us two giveaways
column2: one we knew about—For the King
column3: which Epic revealed last week—and another that
column4: as far as I know
column5: is a surprise bonus. For the King is a strategy roguelike about misfit adventurers who strike out to right the wrongs that have befallen their kingdom.  ""It's a goofy dungeon romp personified
column6: with the kind of playful character that has become so popular in Dungeons & Dragons actual play podcasts
column8: but also ""often a difficult
column9: ruthless game"" that will not hesitate to kill you.  Your party of three heroes can be controlled by a solo players
column10: but it's really best enjoyed as a co-op experience. The second game going out free this week is Metro: Last Light Redux
column14: above) the tunnels of the Moscow Metro.  Last Light is more forgiving than its predecessor
column16: and the Redux release includes a range of new modes and features
column18: and all DLC.  And bar none
column19: it's one of the best post-apoc shooters you can get your hands on.  For the King and Metro: Last Light Redux are free until February 11.  After that comes Halcyon 6: Lightspeed Edition
column20: a ""massively enhanced version"" of the 2016 sci-fi base-building strategy RPG.  For even more free games
